condition.narrative: Operation Agreement, Schedule, Section I.AWithout limitation on the provisions of Article V of the Program General Conditions, theImplementing Entity shall carry out the Program in accordance with financial management, procurement and environmental and socialmanagement systems acceptable to the Bank, including those set out in the ESSA and the Program Action Plan, which are designed toensure that: 1. the Loan proceeds are used for their intended purposes, with due attention to the principles of economy,efficiency, effectiveness, transparency, and accountability; and2. the actual and potential adverse environmental and socialimpacts of the Program are identified, avoided, minimized, or mitigated, as the case may be, all through an informeddecision-making process.Operation Agreement, Schedule, Section I.BThe Implementing Entity shall recruit, and maintain throughoutthe period of the Operation, a Project Management Consultant (PMC), comprising of experienced and qualified personnel, insufficient numbers and under terms of reference acceptable to the Bank, which shall be responsible for day-to-day implementationand monitoring of the Operation, including, inter alia: (a) monitoring the results under each Results Area under the Program; (b)monitoring compliance with social and environmental obligations; and (c) preparing progress reports and ensuring their timelysubmission to the Bank.Operation Agreement, Schedule, Section I.CThe Implementing Entity shall implement the Program Action Planagreed with the Bank, in a manner and substance satisfactory to the Bank.Operation Agreement, Schedule, Section I.DTheImplementing Entity shall prepare, approve and adopt a Program Operation Manual (POM) in a manner and substance satisfactory to theBank, and thereafter carry out all procurement under the Program in accordance with the provisions of the POM, which manual shallinclude, inter alia, all procurement orders and/or procedures applicable for the Program.Operation Agreement, Schedule, SectionIII.BThe Implementing Entity shall:a. maintain, at all times during the implementation of the Program, one or more IndependentVerification Agent(s) under terms of reference acceptable to the Bank, to verify the data and other evidence supporting theachievement of one or more DLRs as set forth in the table in Schedule 4 to this Agreement and recommend corresponding payments tobe made, as applicable; and b. ensure that the Independent Verification Agent(s) carries out verification and process(es) inaccordance with the Verification Protocol; and (ii) submits to the Bank the corresponding verification reports in a timely mannerand in form and substance satisfactory to the Bank, prior to submission of any withdrawal application under Categories (1) to (8)of the table in Section IV.A of Schedule 2 to the Loan Agreement.

title.narrative: Students benefiting from direct interventions to enhance learning
Decrease in the percentage of Grade 4 students below grade-level proficiency in Mathematics

baseline.value: Based on a SLSA, baseline to be established in Year 1

target.value: 3 percentage point decrease each for Boys, Girls, SC, and ST

title.narrative: Improved school management measured according to a standardized tool with a focus on gender equity

baseline.value: Baseline to be established in Year 1

target.value: Performance gap for average school performance score on the standardized tool reduced by 20 percent

title.narrative: Improved teaching practices measured according to a standardized tool with a focus on gender equity

baseline.value: Baseline to be established in Year 1

target.value: Performance gap for average teacher performance on the standardized tool reduced by 10 percent

baseline.value: CWSN Resource Centers require considerable repair; and SCERT has limited experience of Inclusive Education

title.narrative: School learning environment enhanced with minor repairs, essential facilities, furniture, and electrical fixtures

baseline.value: Initiative to upgrade infrastructure and facilities initiated across 15,000 schools. Likely to be completed by July 2021

title.narrative: Social audit monitoring mechanism expanded to to promote prevention and monitoring of on-campus harassment and early marriage amongst girl students

baseline.value: Limited capacity and understanding amongst Parents Committees and panchayat representatives about risks of SRGBV and/or earlymarriage.

target.value: At least 5 blocks adopt a revised social audit monitoring mechanism that integrates preventive and redressal measures on SRGBV andrisks of early marriage amongst adolescent girls.

title.narrative: Improved capacity of Anganwadi workers to provide Early Childhood Education

baseline.value: No long-term in-service training program available for Anganwadi workers

target.value: 75 percent of Anganwadi workers complete 120 days of training

title.narrative: Improved teacher capacity to support early grade education and preparatory schooling

baseline.value: No long-term term in-service training program available for Early Grade teachers

target.value: 75 percent of early grade (including preparatory grades in tribal schools) teachers complete 60 days training program

title.narrative: Increased use of diagnostic assessment tools for provision of remedial support

baseline.value: SAC in process of initiating a system of periodic diagnostic assessment with standardized test items and corresponding teacherresource book for remedial support

title.narrative: Improved access to Personalized Adaptive Learning (PAL) in residential schools catering to girls and tribal students

baseline.value: State government yet to test and assess at scale the possible impact of PAL on student learning levels

target.value: SCERT Assessment Cell led evaluation of PAL intervention completed

title.narrative: Improved knowledge of DRM, school safety, and climate change amongst decentralized education functionaries and school leaders

baseline.value: State has created a cadre of master trainers but is yet to initiate a state-wide training program

title.narrative: Increased number of school leaders demonstrating key leadership competencies

baseline.value: State is yet to initiate a structured professional development program for school leaders

target.value: 75 percent of school leaders demonstrate at least 4 (of 12) competencies on the pre-defined framework

title.narrative: Improved planning, management and implementation capacity at state and district level educational institutions

baseline.value: System of AWPB, and for measuring quality of service provision to be mainstreamed; State Education MIS to be developed

target.value: 75 percent of recipients of need-based teacher training and school leadership training report the same to be of satisfactory quality

title.narrative: Improved availability of need based in-service training

baseline.value: System of need based teacher training yet to be operationalized

target.value: 50 percent teachers provided with access to need based teacher training

title.narrative: Students benefiting from direct interventions to enhance learning - Female
